p: The ML phylogeny was used as a starting tree for Bayesian time-scaled phylogenetic analysis using BEAST 1.10.2 ( http://beast.community/index.html) [ 37]. We employed a stringent model selection analysis using both path-sampling (PS) and stepping stone (SS) procedures to estimate the most appropriate molecular clock model for the Bayesian phylogenetic analysis [ 38]. We tested: a) the strict molecular clock model, which assumes a single rate across all phylogeny branches, and b) the more flexible uncorrelated relaxed molecular clock model with a lognormal rate distribution (UCLN) [ 39]. Both SS and PS estimators indicated the strict molecular clock (Bayes Factor = 4.3) as the best fitted model to the dataset under analysis. Besides, we have used the he HKY+G4 codon partitioned (CP)1+2,3 substitution model and the Bayesian SkyGrid coalescent model of population size and growth [ 39, 40]. We computed MCMC (Markov chain Monte Carlo) duplicate runs of 50 million states each, sampling every 5.000 steps for the ECSA-BR dataset. Convergence of MCMC chains was checked using Tracer v.1.7.1 [ 41]. Maximum clade trees were summarized from the MCMC samples using TreeAnnotator ( http://beast.community/index.html) after discarding 10% as burn-in.
